docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Jerrold L. Nadler, Borough President Scott M. Stringer and Councilman Alan J. Gerson, all Manhattan Democrats, held a news conference yesterday at Stuyvesant High School to urge the federal government to pay for research, medical screenings and health insurance for students who attended school in Lower Manhattan after the 9/11 terrorist attack. They were joined by Amit Friedlander, who graduated from Stuyvesant in 2002. Mr. Friedlander, a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, recently received a diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma and suspects toxic dust from ground zero was a cause. Federal officials have acknowledged delays in helping responders and recovery workers who were sickened at ground zero, but the effect on students in Lower Manhattan has only recently received public attention. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Care For Students Near Ground Zero

docs.abstract: Three prominent Manhattan Democrats join former Stuyvesant High School student Amit Friedlander at news conference; urge federal government to focus attention on health care for students who attended school in Lower Manhattan after 9/11 attacks; Friedlander believes toxic dust exposure from nearby ground zero was cause of recently diagnosed Hodgkin's lymphoma (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the past five springs, a pair of Baltimore Orioles has returned to our yard to nest. This year I was worried. The last I had seen of the dazzling orange patriarch, he was bravely, desperately leading a screeching redtail hawk away from his brood. Then they all vanished. Thus when Daddy-O returned this spring, I rejoiced -- and followed the flash of wings to the hammocklike nest swinging high in our maple tree. The fledging of the ensuing baby orioles took place at a tender time in our human nest; our 16-year-old son, Sam, had gotten his driver's permit. It was a milestone I've dreaded since he began taking solid food. So it was only natural that I would do the sappy Mom thing and anthropomorphize the avian drama. I envied Mama Oriole her apparent sangfroid as the baby birds plunged, flapping, into the void. The female chick was cautious, taking short test flights to nearby branches. Her two snazzy brothers favored the kamikaze approach; death-defying free falls landed them, tweeting and flailing, in the trumpet vine. Every time they made it back to the nest, a squawky fracas ensued that sounded to my fretful maternal ears like a warbled equivalent of ''What were you thinking?''

headline.main: Teaching New Motor Skills, and Stepping Aside
